author: sky.cactus
content: For the record, I *hate* the idea of adding complexity (both to clients and to UX) because a bunch of contracts were written against the advice of security experts.  I (and others) have been telling people for *years* to not limit gas to calls and that gas costs can change up or down over time.  Some people *ignored* that advice.  I don't think we should punish everyone because those people ignored the advice.

author: sky.cactus
content: I can appreciate giving some time for people to migrate to new contracts, e.g., assert that we'll be doing some drastic gas repricing 12 months from now and that they should start planning for it... but I don't think that we should forever be stuck because those people didn't heed warnings.

content: I'm reading over these Oil proposals and they start with the assumption "we cannot change gas costs".  Where is the appropriate place to argue that we *SHOULD* be able to change gas costs?

author: sky.cactus

author: Deleted User
content: <@!301186049323958275> thank you for expressing your opinion on the Oil proposal. It is much more useful to hear this than to hear nothing. We will however continue to develop Oil proposal for a bit, and also use it as a "case-study" for testing a new EVM semantics. One thing I will say in response so far is that it was under my influence that we have separated Oil proposal from the "Witness pricing" theme, because I though it would make it less clear. I still believe that even without the context of Stateless Ethereum, researching and developing oil helps elucidate lots of fundamental things about gas, and why certain things were a design mistake. In the context of Stateless Ethereum, oil is mostly the result of the desire not to try to apportion the charge for the witness across various opcodes, but instead decouple it from the instructions, and make the block witnesses be as much independent from the specifics of EVM as possible. Eventually, I think we might even deprecate gas as it is
